data: Graduates of Amherst College pursue a wide array of career paths and further educational opportunities, reflecting the adaptability, critical thinking, and intellectual curiosity cultivated during their time here. Our commitment to student outcomes is rooted in an interdisciplinary education that prepares students for post-graduate employment and lifelong learning, purpose, and professional agility. The Loeb Center for Career Exploration and Planning provides students with advising, resources, and alumni networks critical to translating their education into concrete and rewarding post-graduation plans. Image Kyndall Ash ’18 Major: Math and Sociology Pursued her passion for Digital Marketing and Public Relations through internships. Managed The Option , a consignment textbook company for Amherst students. An active member of the Choral Society and the all-female a cappella group, the Sabrinas. Accepted a job at LinkedIn. Currently an MBA candidate at Wharton. Image Olivia Geiger ’21 Major: Environmental Science and English Participated in the Loeb Center's Sustainability Careers trek to Boston Appointed as Editor-in-Chief of the Amherst Student newspaper, leading a team of writers Worked at the US Fish and Wildlife Service as a climate resilience writer Enrolled in NYU after graduation to pursue her master's in journalism in environmental reporting Image Aidan Orr ’24 Major: Statistics and Law, Jurisprudence, and Social Thought As a Schupf Fellow, he engaged in intensive summer research on the intersection of secrecy and the death penalty Co-founded “Amherst Students for Democracy,” a club that connects students with internship opportunities at pro-democracy organizations. Accepted position with Lawyers Defending American Democracy Image Bryce Bares ’00 Major: Music Considered becoming a composer for TV and film. Attended law school at Boston College. Pursued entrepreneurial endeavors, including software that helps online poker players make the best next move. Became the owner/operator of every Dunkin‘ Donut in central and Eastern Nebraska. Image Ike Zhang ’16 Major: Chemistry and Asian Languages & Civilizations Held multiple internships, including the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and an investment firm. Accepted a consulting job with EY Parthenon. Pursued his MBA through MIT’s Sloan School of Management. Transitioned to creative development roles with several entertainment companies. Became a Talent Agent for United Talent Agency. Image P. Gabrielle Foreman ’86 Major: American Studies Received her PhD in Ethnic Studies from the University of California, Berkeley. Became a professor of American Literature, and African American Studies & History at Penn State University. Is the founding director of the Colored Conventions Project, a digital initiative that documents historical Black organizing efforts, and was selected to be a MacArthur Fellow in 2022. Each year, the First Destination Report shares the postgraduate plans of our most recent graduating class. The Loeb Center for Career Exploration and Planning collects data through the end of the calendar year, following standards set by the National Association of Colleges and Employers (NACE), to capture opportunities secured by recent graduates. 94% of our graduates are employed, continuing education, pursuing a fellowship, volunteering, or serving in the military within six months of graduation. Our alumni take a variety of paths in life. Some are prominent on the world scene, and others contribute to society in equally important, though less public, ways. A liberal arts education prepares students for careers, volunteer activities, and individual interests and pursuits that are personally meaningful. It’s not about what you have done since Amherst, but who you have become. Read about a few of our alumni below, and see more alumni profiles .
